keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was sentenced to between five years and life in prison for first-degree rape in Utah after being identified through a decade-old DNA match.

Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020, with an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, but investigators found inconsistencies and suspects he was alive and living under false identities.
He fled the U.S. after being charged and was arrested in Scotland in 2023 due to recognition of his tattoos, including a Brown University crest, from an Interpol notice.
Rossi used at least a dozen aliases over the years to evade capture, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight.
He was convicted in two separate cases in August and September 2025 for raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, with the first conviction leading to sentencing on October 20, 2025.
The victim in the first case described a pattern of financial manipulation, emotional control, and violence, including being asked to pay for dates, lend money, and take on debt for engagement rings.
Rossi was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender and faces fraud charges in Ohio from 2008 sex-related convictions.
The case highlights the importance of DNA database use in solving cold cases and the dangers of predatory behavior by individuals who evade justice through deception and aliases.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man whose real name is Nicholas Alahverdian, was sentenced to between five years and life in prison in Utah for raping two women in 2008. After being identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog, authorities discovered that Rossi had allegedly faked his death in 2020 by claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. He fled to Scotland, where he was arrested in 2023 due to recognition of distinctive tattoos, including one from Brown University, linked to an Interpol notice. Rossi used multiple aliases, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight, to evade capture. He was convicted in two separate trials in August and September 2025, with the first conviction resulting in sentencing on October 20, 2025. The victim described a pattern of financial manipulation, emotional control, and violence, and emphasized the need for accountability and safety. Rossi previously faced sex offender registration issues in Rhode Island and fraud charges in Ohio. The case highlights the importance of DNA databases, the dangers of predatory behavior, and the global efforts required to bring fugitives to justice.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
